unredacted: Onome Amaechi Chiamaka (Principal Appellant), and Adeboye Agnes Chiamaka and Ayebatari Mustapha Chiamaka (Minor Appellants) are citizens of Nigeria. They appeal a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) rejecting their claims for refugee protection. They claim that if they return to Nigeria, either Minor Appellant may be forced to become the Chief Priest of their father’s ancestral town, and all of the Appellants may be harmed or killed for refusing. The Minor Appellants’ father—the Principal Appellant’s estranged husband—was the Principal Claimant for the family at the RPD. His appeal is proceeding separately., The Appellants present new evidence about the threat from his clan with respect to the priesthood, as well as new evidence that the Principal Appellant fears domestic violence from her estranged husband.

unredacted: I find there is sufficient evidence to indicate a serious possibility that the estranged husband may engage in further violence against the Principal Appellant if both are returned to Nigeria. Where the Principal Appellant is concerned, her estranged husband has behaved erratically in both words and actions. He has begged her to continue their relationship and then turned on her with violence or rejected and humiliated her. This behaviour is part of a pattern that can include escalating violence, recognized in the Chairperson’s Gender Guideline. Experts have found that the most dangerous time for a person who has suffered domestic violence actually may be upon and after leaving her abuser. In this case, the violence that her estranged husband has inflicted on her previously may be provoked anew by the separation of the family’s refugee appeals, and by his beliefs about the Principal Appellant’s sexual orientation. She testified that he is spreading rumours in both Canada and Nigeria that she associates with lesbians and she is trying to take the children from him.

unredacted: The Principal Appellant has said that she would like her estranged husband to have supervised access to their children, and her dealings with the family court in Canada have been consistent with her stated desire. Some abusers use children and custody as a means of continuing to control their ex-partners. In this case, the Principal Appellant testified—and her estranged husband acknowledged—that he has hacked her email to read her correspondence. When she unblocked him on social media to allow him to speak with the children, he used that opportunity to abuse her verbally. The Principal Appellant states that he continues to send her “insulting and belittling messages, sometimes many in a single day.” In addition, he used a meeting in a neutral place with supervised access to the children to follow them to their new place of residence. In Nigerian law and society, there exist presumptions that would favour the estranged husband: male children usually go to the father once they are deemed old enough to be separated from their mother; and “moral misconduct” of the mother militates in favour of custody by the father, even for young children. In this case, the estranged husband has laid a foundation to prove to a Nigerian court the Principal Appellant’s alleged “moral misconduct” by spreading rumours that she associates with lesbians. Same sex relationships are a crime in their country.

unredacted: The Appellants’ fear is linked to the refugee Convention by their membership in three particular social groups: the Principal Appellant’s gender as a woman, her sexual orientation, and the Appellants’ status as members of the ex-husband’s family. The Principal Appellant did not meet the estranged husband’s expectations about their respective gender roles. In Nigeria, there are “widely held notions that women should be subordinate to men, and that married women are the property of their husbands. This produces a power dynamic which justifies abusive behaviour perpetrated by a husband, including the use of violence.” The Principal Appellant expected to work outside the home and to have her husband’s help with the care of their children. She refused to submit to his demands and stood up to him forcefully. She resisted his attempts to isolate her from friends and family. The Minor Appellants are dependents of their mother, and their physical and psychological safety is inextricably linked to hers. They have borne serious emotional consequences from their father’s violence against their mother, such that child protection authorities in Canada view his access to them as a risk.

unredacted: The Appellants also fear harm because the Minor Appellants are next in line after their father to become the chief priest of Ozoro Town in Delta State. Their parents have refused to participate, or to allow the Minor Appellants’ participation because the fetish practices conflict with their Christian beliefs. As a result of the vacant chief priest role, the clan believes it is without spiritual protection. The Appellants testified that the King of the clan sent men to demand that the estranged husband become the chief priest. The documentary evidence substantiates that conflict may occur in clans and families where someone has refused a spiritual role. I find that seeking to restore spiritual protection is a strong motivation for the family of the estranged husband to find and coerce the Principal Appellant and her sons. Their traditional belief is that no one may succeed the males of this family in the role of chief priest until they are all dead., Documentary evidence also supports the Appellants’ testimony that the priest role need not be passed to the eldest son., This corroborates a risk to each of the Minor Appellants. The Principal Appellant’s risk arises from her outspoken rejection of the chief priest role for her male family members, which also contravenes the clan’s expectations about a woman’s role in the family., In addition, her refusal aggravates a relationship with her estranged husband’s family that was already fraught with dislike and tension. If the estranged husband were to relocate to the IFA of Ibadan, the risk to the Appellants would be increased by his presence, which might alert clan members to their presence also.

unredacted: The Principal Appellant has said that she would like her estranged husband to have supervised access to their children, and her dealings with the family court in Canada have been consistent with her stated desire. Some abusers use children and custody as a means of continuing to control their ex-partners. In this case, the Principal Appellant testified—and her estranged husband acknowledged—that he has hacked her email to read her correspondence. When she unblocked him on social media to allow him to speak with the children, he used that opportunity to abuse her verbally. The Principal Appellant states that he continues to send her “insulting and belittling messages, sometimes many in a single day.” In addition, he used a meeting in a neutral place with supervised access to the children to follow them to their new place of residence. In Nigerian law and society, there exist presumptions that would favour the estranged husband: male children usually go to the father once they are deemed old enough to be separated from their mother; and “moral misconduct” of the mother militates in favour of custody by the father, even for young children. In this case, the estranged husband has laid a foundation to prove to a Nigerian court the Principal Appellant’s alleged “moral misconduct” by spreading rumours that she associates with lesbians. Same sex relationships are a crime in their country.

unredacted: The Appellants’ fear is linked to the refugee Convention by their membership in three particular social groups: the Principal Appellant’s gender as a woman, her sexual orientation, and the Appellants’ status as members of the ex-husband’s family. They have borne serious emotional consequences from their father’s violence against their mother, such that child protection authorities in Canada view his access to them as a risk.

unredacted: I find that the Appellants have discharged their burden to overcome the presumption of adequate state protection in Ibadan. Although the Principal Appellant is well-educated and comparatively well-off, she is unlikely to be taken seriously by police if she approaches them for protection—protection either from her estranged husband or from his clan in the matter of the chief priest role. Police are known to reject complaints in disputes related to domestic violence and traditional leadership because they are viewed as private matters. Furthermore, police protection is reportedly less available to female complainants, and even less so if they are unable to pay a bribe. unredacted: Even if I am wrong about the first prong, I find the IFA in Ibadan does not meet the second prong either. The standard for unreasonableness is quite high, requiring the Appellants to bear inconvenience and discomfort, reduced quality of life, loss of status and disappointment, but not danger to their life or safety. I have considered whether it would endanger the Appellants’ life or safety to expect the Principal Appellant, a single mother, to work outside her field of expertise, in a strange city, with no family connections, and in fear of running into her abusive former husband, including at a place of Christian worship. unredacted: In summary, it would be both unsafe and unreasonable to expect the Appellants to relocate in Ibadan. The similarity of the Principal Appellant’s field of endeavour to that of the estranged husband’s influential uncle makes her vulnerable to be found quite easily. Moreover, her status as a single female head of household, and her sexual orientation make it more likely than not that the Appellants will face serious discrimination, possibly amounting to persecution, cruel treatment, or a risk to their life. They cannot be required to live in hiding to find safety and they remain at risk of being harmed, even in the proposed IFA. The cumulative challenges they would face upon relocation make the IFA unreasonable.
